discussion.content:
B. TLS 1.2, because there is not SSL 1.3.
There is SSL 1.0, 2.0, and 3.0, and also TLS 1.0, 1.1, 1.2, and 1.3.

comments.content:
SNMPv3 primary purpose is routing and switching, such as monitoring the network with secure protocols. Does not address browser-based, SSL and TLS does 
answer B. TLS 1.2

discussion.content:
And why not SNMPv3?
The Simple Network Management Protocol version 3 (SNMPv3) is a standard for managing devices on IP-based networks. Earlier versions of SNMP sent all traffic in clear text. SNMP v3 sends all data encrypted.
According to this website it is SSHv2. https://www.globalknowledge.com/us-en/resources/resource-library/articles/how-to-secure-cisco-routers-and-switches/#gref

comments.content: SSH is for CLI access, question specifies "browser based", therefore TLS 1.2 is correct.
browser= HTTP + TLS 1.2+ Secured Browser Based!

questions.question_text: During a security audit of a company's network, unsecure protocols were found to be in use. A network administrator wants to ensure browser-based access to company switches is using the most secure protocol. Which of the following protocols should be implemented?

While monitoring the SIEM, a security analyst observes traffic from an external IP to an IP address of the business network on port 443. Which of the following protocols would MOST likely cause this traffic?

discussion.content: HTTPS uses port 443. HTTPS uses SSL for encryption.

If you use Http over Tls port number 80 you have to know that your are using Unsecure protocol/ dtat in clear. 
However, if use Http over SSL you have to know that you are using https which is a secured way of web activities. Https uses port 443 over s a secure socket layer ( SSL)

questions.question_text: A technician is required to configure updates on a guest operating system while maintaining the ability to quickly revert the changes that were made while testing the updates. Which of the following should the technician implement?

discussion.content: B and C are the concepts, but the name of the technology that implements B and C is called Snapshots.
Keywords > guest os, indicating that it is a VM environment, quickly revert > indicating or describing the purpose of a snapshot.

Looks like Snapshot or can also be revert to know state. but wait they are both the same according to CompTIA.... lol which one to pick. I'll go with mobb rules... 

NON-PERSISTENCE
There are various mechanisms for ensuring non-persistence:
Snapshot/revert to known state—This is a saved system state that can be reapplied to the instance.
Rollback to known configuration—A physical instance might not support snapshots but has an "internal" mechanism for restoring the baseline system configuration, such as Windows System Restore.
Live boot media—another option is to use an instance that boots from read-only storage to memory rather than being installed on a local read/write hard disk.
No adequate info in the question, cant decide answer is Snapshot
Shadow Copy is Microsoft backend technology for doing snapshots, but doesn't apply to Hyper-V, which is Microsoft's hypervisor.

Yes, Snapshot. The Hypervisor (the OS that interacts directly with the physical hardware) creates the Virtual Machine (VM). The VM then presents the virtual hardware to the Guest OS which is the OS that runs on the VM. Best practice is to take a backup or snapshot of the VM before making changes in case they don't work, you can revert back to the snapshot before the changes were made.
VM? snap in virtual machine , in workstation C

comments.content: The question mentions a “guest” OS, which is like we commonly call a computer in a virtual environment.

discussion.content:
This same style question is on jason dion udemy test and the correct answer is 
RAT

Key word look the last row file name notepad.exe
 
What is Noteoad.exe (QAZ Trojan )Program?
This backdoor Trojan allows hackers to access and control an infected system. TROJ_QAZ was initially distributed as "Notepad.exe" but might also appear with different filenames. Once an infected file is executed, TROJ_QAZ modifies the Windows registry so that it becomes active every time Windows is started. TROJ_QAZ also renames the original "notepad.exe" file to "note.com" and then copies itself as "notepad.exe" to the Windows folder. This way, the Trojan is also launched every time a user runs Notepad. TROJ_QAZ also attempts to spread itself to other shared drives on local networks. This Trojan does not mass email itself out to lists in the users address book however.

questions.question_text: An organization is building a new customer services team, and the manager needs to keep the team focused on customer issues and minimize distractions. The users have a specific set of tools installed, which they must use to perform their duties. Other tools are not permitted for compliance and tracking purposes. Team members have access to the Internet for product lookups and to research customer issues. Which of the following should a security engineer employ to fulfill the requirements for the manager?

discussion.content: I think the answer should be D. Whitelisting

comments.content: What do you mean? Where in the question or answers is it implied that you can't whitelist the apps on the workstation? What else would "configure whitelisting for the team" mean? It doesn't mean whitelisting members of a team lol. It definitely means whitelisting applications.

discussion.content: The options seem to be deliberately crafted to mislead people. You cannot configure whitelisting for the team, it can only be done on the workstation. Since the option to whitelist the application on the workstation is not on the list, the closest one is to use containerisation

comments.content: This doesn't seem clear. whitelisting applications should be the correct answer.containerisation is separation not restriction. management wants them to concentrate on a particular set of tools .whitelisting these tools gives them the opportunity to work only with these tools under certain conditions

discussion.content:
C is the answers
Containerization allows developers to create and deploy applications faster and more securely. With traditional methods, code is developed in a specific computing environment which, when transferred to a new location, often results in bugs and errors.
That C does make sense to me how ll containerization prevent the team from downloading other applications
Containerization = Virtualization = VDIs. This what we do at work for teams who need very specific settings/programs and nothing else.
D is sensible answer

How do you implement containerazation on a WORKSTATION? Anyone?

All comptia study resources refer to containers in terms of mobile devices ONLY.

Answer D with 100% confidence.

comments.content:
Use Docker as the Container engine to run on workstation and use Kubernetes to control it. 
At the end of the day if the option is "whitelisting a team" I will skip it and go with containerization.

I think the given answer is correct. Whitelisting is not enough for the answer, we need more. Here is the key point: "Other tools are not permitted for compliance and tracking purposes." 
Containerization: A mobile app or workspace that runs within a partitioned environment to prevent other (unauthorized) apps from interacting with it.

Which of the following should a security engineer employ to fulfill the requirements for the manager?
-WAF -A web application firewall is a specific form of application firewall that filters, monitors, and blocks HTTP traffic to and from a web service. So we can block Facebook, Instagram etc.

I go with WAF!

D. So this is why I’m going with D on this one:

question: ...The users have a specific set of tools installed, which they must use to perform their duties. Other tools are not permitted for compliance and tracking purposes.

An application whitelist is a list of applications and application components that are authorized for use in an organization. Application whitelisting technologies use whitelists to control which applications are permitted to execute on a host. This helps to stop the execution of malware, unlicensed software, and other unauthorized software. -- https://www.nist.gov/publications/guide-application-whitelisting
